headline: Owls Win South Florida Diving Invite
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's and women's diving teams wrapped up the two-day South Florida Diving Invitational hosted by FIU, sweeping both competitions. Junior Trevor Kuhn won two of the three events over the course of the two-day meet, victorious on the platform and 1mtr diving competitions. Miles Buchart was the meet's highest individual scorer with 37.00 total points. On the women's side, senior Grace Powell totaled 31.00 total individual points, tied for most on the women's side. RESULTS (MEN): 1. Florida Atlantic: 162.00 2. Keiser: 28.00 (WOMEN): 1. Florida Atlantic: 125.00 2. FIU: 118.00 3. Keiser: 43.00 4. St Thomas: 15.00 ON DECK The Owls will have a few weeks off before gearing up for the Patriot Midseason Invitational hosted by George Mason. The three-day meet begins on Wednesday, Nov. 19 with competition wrapping up on Saturday, Nov. 22. FAU will be looking for a third consecutive team sweep of the meet. SCHEDULE For the full 2025-26 swim & dive schedule, click HERE. ROSTER For the full 2025-26 swim & dive roster, click HERE. OWLS ON SOCIAL MEDIA For complete coverage of FAU swimming & diving, follow us on social media (@FAUSWIMDIVE)

headline: Owls Fall in Four at Tulane
content: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì Florida Atlantic volleyball drops a four-setter, 3-1 (25-17, 26-24, 18-25, 25-20) to the Tulane Green Wave on the road Friday at Avron B. Fogelman Arena. The Owls fall to 17-9 on the season and 8-5 in American play, while Tulane moves to 11-13 overall and 3-10 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED Tulane took the opening lead, holding a 15-11 advantage through the first set media break. The Owls battled back to within three, cutting the deficit to 18-15 after a kill from Kierstin Bevelle, but FAU couldn't close out the rally as the Green Wave captured the set on a 7-2 run to take the opening set 25-17. The Owls opened the second set strong, taking the opening lead at 4-1 Tulane answered back, cutting the Owls' lead to one at 7-6, however, Kayla Richardson helped spark a 4-0 Owl run with a kill and a block assist, along with a pair of Green Wave attacking errors to extend FAU's lead back to five, 11-6, pushing the Green Wave to call their first timeout of the set. Tulane cut the deficit in half shortly after, forcing the Owls to call a timeout of their own, holding a 13-11 lead. The Green Wave battled, eventually bringing the set even at 19-19. The Owls maintained the lead, holding a 23-22 advantage, but the Green Wave had late set success with a 4-1 run to earn the second set win, 26-24, and a two-set lead. Tulane held the early advantage in the third, opening the frame on an 8-5 run. However, following an FAU timeout, the Owls locked in to outscore the Green Wave 11-3 and take a five-point advantage at 16-11. The Owls fought and closed out the third set on a 6-5 run, as Anna Hartman registered the kill to take the third, 25-18. FAU fell behind quickly to open the fourth with Tulane building an 11-2 lead to open the frame. However, the Owls scored five unanswered points, capped off by a Zoe Winford kill, to cut the lead to four, 11-7. FAU kept the set within four through a 19-15 Tulane advantage, but couldn't close the gap with the Green Wave taking the fourth 25-20 for the match win. STATS & NOTES Olivia Hart and Bevelle led the way for the Owls. Hart finished with a team-best 14 kills, notching her 11th double-double of the season with 13 digs, as well as tying for a team-high two blocks and adding a pair of aces. Bevelle joined Hart in double-figures with 11 kills and added two digs and a block in the match. Emsley Venard once again dished out a team-leading 20 assists. Isabelle Northam recorded a team-best 18 digs. As a team, the Owls held advantages over the Green Wave in kills (52), assists (50), and service aces (8). UP NEXT The Owls will look to bounce back on Sunday, Nov. 9, as they visit conference leader Rice for a 2 p.m. ET first serve inside Tudor Fieldhouse and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Take Homecoming Game Versus Tulsa
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Behind three touchdowns from Easton Messer and three takeaways from the defense, the Florida Atlantic football team defeated Tulsa in Saturday afternoon's Homecoming game at Flagler Credit Union Stadium by a score of 40-21. The Owls (4-5, 3-3) dropped 40 points at home for the third time this season with a complete game on both sides of the ball against the Golden Hurricane (2-7, 0-6), winning the turnover margin battle 3-1. VIDEO RECAP THE BEGINNING Starting out on defense, redshirt senior DB Terez Reid picked off a pass on the second play of the game, the Owls' first interception of the year. FAU's first drive on offense culminated in a 39-yard field goal by Garrison Smith, extending its program record to six consecutive games with a score on the opening possession. After a goal-line stand on defense, redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp continued his growing connection with redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt, hitting him down the sideline where Platt took it 47 yards for a touchdown and a 10-0 lead. THE TURNING POINT Following two Tulsa field goals early in the second, Veltkamp found a wide-open Messer for a 44-yard score to up the score to 17-6, the first of 21 unanswered points to close the half. It was then redshirt senior DB Damarius McGhee's turn to make a game-changing play, scooping up a fumble at the goal line and returning it 95 yards for the score. With the defense back on the field, senior DB Chris Keys Jr. made an interception to give it right back to the Owls, setting up the second score to Messer on an 11-yard strike to send FAU to the locker room up 31-6. THE FINISH After a quiet third quarter, a drive commanded by graduate QB Zach Gibson gave the Owls 40. A 30-yard grab from Platt on 4th-and-one flea flicker set up Messer's nine-yard score, his third of the day. Two sacks ‚Äì one by junior DE Deshaun Batiste and the other by freshman DE Josh Roberts ‚Äì kept Tulsa out of the end zone the rest of the way. OFFENSE Messer's hat trick was the first multi-score game of his collegiate career. He becomes just the sixth receiver in program history to haul in three touchdown catches in a single game. For the second week in a row, Platt recorded a 100+ yard receiving game with 114 on five catches. Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton logged the first 100+ yard game of his career, with 107 yards on just 11 carries. He ripped off a 50-yard run, the longest of his career, to end the first quarter. DEFENSE McGhee's 95-yard fumble return is the second longest in program history, yardage not seen since the second game in the 2001 inaugural season. Leading the way in tackles was redshirt junior Leon Hart Jr. with 12. Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky recorded 11 tackles, his fourth straight game in double digits. In addition to the three takeaways, the Owls' defensive unit forced three turnovers-on-downs, and recorded five sacks, eight tackles for loss and six pass breakups POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior QB Caden Veltkamp Graduate QB Zach Gibson Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Junior WR Jayshon Platt Graduate OL Alex Atcavage Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid Redshirt Senior DB Damarius McGhee PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Tulsa at Florida Atlantic UP NEXT The Owls will travel for their final road game of the 2025 season, heading to New Orleans for a matchup with Tulane on Saturday, Nov. 15. Kickoff is at 4 p.m. ET on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Owls End the Night with Victory Over Charleston in Field of 68
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team opened up the Field of 68 Tip-Off with a wire-to-wire 94-77 victory over Charleston on Saturday evening at Liberty Arena. The Owls (2-0) jumped out to a double-digit lead over the Cougars (1-1) early and did not look back the rest of the way. In a typical balanced offensive showing under Head Coach John Jakus, six players scored in double figures, with all 13 who stepped onto the court recording points. FIRST HALF Like the previous game, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool opened scoring. Five straight points from redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams gave the Owls an early 12-3 lead, with a dunk from junior center Vincent Neugebauer putting the team ahead by double digits. The lead grew to as big as 19, with a late shot from junior guard Kanaan Carlyle sending the Owls to the locker room with a 48-32 advantage. Defensively, Florida Atlantic did not surrender a field goal to four Charleston starters, holding them to a combined 0-for-11 shooting. SECOND HALF Two triples from junior forward Xander Pintelon put Florida Atlantic up by 20 five minutes in the second half. The Owls then worked their way in the paint, with sophomore Maxim Logue connecting on four shots in a four-minute span. Florida Atlantic led by as much as 25 and reached the 90-point mark with a three-pointer from redshirt freshman Liam Dayco-Green in his collegiate debut. PRESS CONFERENCES STATS & NOTES The Owls made the most of their second chance opportunities, outscoring the Cougars 24-7. Florida Atlantic converted 11 shots behind the arc, their second straight game with 10+ to open the season. Carlyle led the team in scoring for the second game in a row, this time with 14. Logue shot a perfect six-for-six from the field. Vanterpool had another balanced statline, logging six rebounds and five assists. Three Owls recorded the first points of their collegiate careers: Neugebauer, redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, and Dayco-Green FAU holds a 4-1 record in the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close the Field of 68 Tip-Off, facing host team Liberty on Sunday, Nov. 9. Tipoff is at 6 p.m. on the Field of 68's YouTube channel. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Jackson‚Äôs Buzzer-Beater Seals Road Win at Kennesaw State
content: KENNESAW, Ga. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team moves to 2-0 on the season, notching Coach Freeland's first road win at Florida Atlantic with a 69-68 victory over Kennesaw State on Saturday at VyStar Arena. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls trailed for much of the first quarter before Michiyah Simmons tied it at 10 with 4:33 left to go in the first. The game began to pick up speed, going back and forth, ending the first quarter with Florida Atlantic leading 19-16 off a Destyne Jackson 3-pointer. FAU started the second quarter strong, extending their lead to 26-19 in the first two minutes. Kennesaw State cut the Florida Atlantic lead to three at 29-26 by the media timeout. Jackson put the Owls' lead back to six with 30 seconds remaining in the half. The Owls entered halftime with a 37-31 lead. To start the third quarter, Kennesaw State committed three team fouls, and the Owls' lead extended to 10, 41-31, within the first minute of play. KSU began to close the lead before a Grace Carstensen 3-pointer extended the lead back to seven. The Owls then gained their largest lead of the contest at the six-minute mark with the score standing at 51-40. FAU held its lead at nine through the end of the third, taking a 61-52 lead into the final 10 minutes of play. Kennesaw State made a run in the fourth quarter, keeping Florida Atlantic from scoring for over two minutes. The Owls' lead shrank to one point, sitting at 64-63 with 3:48 to go in the game. KSU took the lead with two minutes to go in the game before Jackson called game with a corner 3-pointer with two seconds left to capture the win, 69-68. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we played really well for the first three quarters, and then the fatigue set in a little bit, but I'm extremely proud of the fight and the grit to finish the game. Destyne's shot at the end of the fourth was huge. Just really proud of our team effort and our belief that we would pull it out." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Four Florida Atlantic players finished in double figures. Jackson with 13, Simmons with 12, Jess Moors with 11, and Carstensen with 10. Vivian Onugha led the team in rebounds on the night with four. Simmons had a team-leading five assists. The Owls were 50 percent from both field goal and 3-point range on the night, matching up well to Kennesaw State's 48.1 field goal percentage and 16.7 three-point percentage. UP NEXT The Owls head to Coral Gables to face Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13, at 7 p.m. inside the Watsco Center on ACC Network Extra. FOLLOW THE OWLS For updates, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Florida Atlantic Hosts Ring Ceremony
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic softball gathered on Saturday morning to celebrate the success of the 2025 season, with the Owls receiving championship rings for their second consecutive American Conference regular season title and NCAA Tournament appearance. After becoming the school's first American Conference champion in 2024, the softball program won back-to-back titles in 2025, achieving 45 wins and a 23-4 conference record. Under third-year Head Coach Jordan Clark, the Owls qualified for the Gainesville Regional for the second year in a row and earned a 5-4 victory over Georgia Tech, their first in an NCAA Regional since 2016. Championship rings were distributed and the award-winning Owls from the previous campaign were recognized, including All-American pitcher Autumn Courtney, American Defensive Player of the Year Jesiana Mora, and All-Conference players Chloe Yeatts, Kylie Hammonds, Ainsley Lambert, Bella Foran, and Destiny Johns. The Owls were honored later in the afternoon at the football Homecoming game as part of the celebration of Florida Atlantic Varsity Champions. GALLERY Gallery: (11-8-2025) Softball Ring Ceremony VIDEO ùòº ùô¢ùô§ùôßùô£ùôûùô£ùôú ùô©ùô§ ùôßùôöùô¢ùôöùô¢ùôóùôöùôß üôå#WIPüèùÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/wGbuYCA2p3‚Äî Florida Atlantic Softball (@FAUSoftball) November 8, 2025 OWLS ON SOCIAL MEDIA To stay up to date on all things FAU softball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUSoftball.

headline: Owls Open Road Slate at Kennesaw State Saturday
content: KENNESAW, Ga. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team will open its 2025-26 road slate on Saturday, Nov. 7, traveling to Kennesaw State for a 7 p.m. tip inside VyStar Arena on ESPN+. MATCHUP INFO Florida Atlantic (1-0) at Kennesaw State (1-0) Date: Saturday, Nov. 7 Time: 7 p.m. ET Location: VyStar Arena in Kennesaw, Ga. GAME COVERAGE TV: ESPN+ Live Stats: Statbroadcast A LOOK AT THE OWLS The Florida Atlantic Owls enter Saturday's matchup 1-0 after earning a season-opening 89-46 win over Florida Memorial. The Owls are led offensively by Vivian Onugha, who scored 24 points in the Owls' season-opener. Grace Carstensen ranks second on the team, scoring 21 points against Florida Memorial.. Zahira Arizmendi and Ineivi Plata tied for a team-best five assists against the Lions. On the glass, the Owls are led by Haley Walker, who pulled down a team-high 14 rebounds, and Onugha, who ranks second on the team, collecting 11 boards to open the season. Onugha also tallied a team-best two steals against Florida Memorial. SCOUTING KENNESAW STATE Kennesaw State enters Saturday's meeting at 1-0 on the season, earning an 85-36 win against Shorter. KSU is led offensively by Shania Nichols, Kailyn Fields, Keyarah Berry, and Trynce Taylor. Nichols scored a team-best 20 points, while Fields, Berry, and Taylor recorded 14, 13, and 10 points, respectively. Taylor paces the Owls on the boards, recording a team-high six rebounds against Shorter. Kaelyn Flowers leads the team in assists, dishing out seven in their season-opener. Flowers also ties with Berry for the team lead in steals, collecting a team-leading three steals each in the opener. SERIES HISTORY Saturday's matchup marks the eighth all-time meeting between Florida Atlantic and Kennesaw State. The Owls lead the series 5-2, including a 2-1 advantage when playing in Kennesaw. LAST TIME OUT: VS. FLORIDA MEMORIAL The Owls earned an 89-46 season-opening win over the Florida Memorial Lions. The victory marked LeAnn Freeland's first win as Florida Atlantic's head coach. Onugha and Carstensen led the way for the Owls. Onugha tallied her first NCAA double-double, with a game-leading career-best 24 points and finishing second on the team with 11 boards. She shot 80 percent (eight-of-10) from the field and added eight free throws. Carstensen also produced a new career-high, scoring 21 points, shooting 64 percent (seven-of-11) from the floor, 67 percent (four-of-) from beyond the arc, and was perfect at the line (three-of-three). As a team, the Owls dominated in nearly every statistical category. FAU shot 55.4 percent from the field, 50 percent from beyond the arc, and 69.6 percent at the line. FAU also dominated the Lions on the boards, outrebounding FMU 45-17 and doubling up the Lions on the defensive glass, 31-15. The Owls also outpaced the Lions in points in the paint, 40 to 28, points off turnovers, 24 to 14, second chance points, 14 to 0, fast break points, 29 to 4, and points off the bench, 48 to 13. UP NEXT Following Saturday's contest, the Owls return to South Florida to continue their three-game road stretch, visiting Miami on Thursday, Nov. 13 for a 7 p.m. tip inside the Watsco Center and on AACNX. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

headline: Owls on the Road for Field of 68 Tip-Off
content: LYNCHBURG, Va. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team will travel to Lynchburg, Virginia, for the third and final edition of the three-team Field of 68 Tip-Off, this year hosted by Liberty. For the Owls' (1-0) opening game of the 2025 round robin, they will face Charleston on Saturday, Nov. 8 with the matchup against the Cougars (1-0) set to begin at 6 p.m. Sunday against the Flames (1-0) will begin at the same time with both games streaming on YouTube. Since the event began in 2023, Florida Atlantic owns a 3-1 record versus the two teams. LAST TIME OUT The Owls began their 2025-26 season with an 83-78 overtime victory over Boston College at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena, the program's first home win over a power conference school since December of 2002. Trailing by nine points with under five minutes remaining, Florida Atlantic staged a comeback culminating in a three-pointer from freshman guard Yohann Sissoko to tie the game. He later converted the go-ahead layup in overtime to take a lead that FAU did not relinquish. Five Owls scored in double figures, led by junior guard Kanaan Carlyle with 19. ABOUT THE OWLS Jakus enters his second season at the helm of the program. In his debut campaign in 2024-25, he was a finalist for the Joe B. Hall Award, given to the nation's top first-year head coach. Under Jakus' watch, the Owls participated in their fourth straight year of postseason play, selected to the 2025 National Invitational Tournament. Returning for the Owls are redshirt junior guard Niccolo Moretti, redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool, and redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, Liam Dayco-Green, and Max Langenfeld. Moretti dished out 115 assists during the 2024-25 season and had just 44 turnovers, ranked 28th nationally in assist/turnover ratio. The Owls welcome 10 newcomers: four true freshmen, four from the transfer portal, and two international players. Guard Josiah Parker was named the American Conference's Preseason Freshman of the Year. Sissoko scored 15 points, the most by an Owl in their collegiate debut since 2018. As a team, Florida Atlantic was ranked sixth in the American's preseason poll. In total, the Owls are represented by seven different countries: the United States, Canada, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Senegal, and France. ABOUT THE COUGARS The Cougars are led by Head Coach Chris Mack in his second campaign with the team. Charleston has achieved four straight winning seasons, with two NCAA Tournament appearances in three years. The Cougars are 1-0 after defeating Tusculum by a score of 79-58 on November 3. Redshirt sophomore center Chol Machot and graduate guard Kendall Taylor each recorded double-doubles in their season debut. In the last meeting between FAU and Charleston at the 2024 Field of 68 Tip-Off, the Owls fell on a buzzer beater in double overtime by a score of 119-116, despite recording the second most points in a game in program history. ABOUT THE FLAMES Head Coach Ritchie McKay is in his 11th season in his second stint and 13th overall leading the team. Liberty is fresh off a 28-7 season in 2024-25 and earned an automatic bid to the 2025 NCAA Tournament. The Flames placed in first in Conference USA's preseason poll. In its season opener, Liberty recorded a 98-57 victory over Kentucky Christian. The Owls hold a 3-1 record over the flames, including wins in the last two years. FAU defeated Liberty in overtime by a score of 77-74 in the 2024 edition of the Field of 68 Tip-Off. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will enjoy a week off from games before returning to action on Monday, Nov. 17 to host Coastal Georgia. Tipoff at the Elly is scheduled for 7 p.m. on ESPN+. SCHEDULE Click here for the 2025-26 schedule. ROSTER Click here for the full 2025-26 men's basketball roster. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

headline: Veterans Appreciation, Homecoming Highlight Saturday‚Äôs Football Game
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. -- Florida Atlantic will honor and celebrate its local and campus military veterans during Saturday's Homecoming football game versus Tulsa. Kickoff is set for 3 p.m. at Flagler Credit Union Stadium with tickets available by calling 1-866-FAU-OWLS or visiting FAUsports.com. Active and former military are encouraged to click here for complimentary tickets using the code FAUMA. It is Homecoming Weekend on campus, with the Owls donning throwback helmets, a nod to the helmet worn by the inaugural FAU football team 25 years ago. Throwback mini helmets, along with a variety of 25th anniversary apparel, are available at ShopFAUsports.com. Saturday's game is presented by Ideal Nutrition. Beginning at 12:30 p.m. when Fan Zone opens outside Flagler Credit Union Stadium, FAU's Military Veterans Student Success Center (MVSSC) and FAU's ROTC will have a presence with military apparatus and activations. Michael Carroll, an FAU student, U.S. Marine Corps Veteran, staff sergeant and drill instructor, will lead the football team out of the tunnel, while Dr. Candy Wilson, Ph.D., a nurse practitioner, FAU professor and associate dean for nursing research and scholarship in the Christine E. Lynn College of Nursing, who is also a retired colonel in the U.S. Air Force Nurse Corps will serve as the honorary captain for the coin toss. Also during the game, 13 ROTC cadets will be sworn in to service during a ceremony on the field. In addition to veterans and military appreciation, the Owls will honor their recent varsity championship teams from Softball (American Conference regular season), Beach Volleyball (CUSA tournament), Women's Tennis (NCAA Tournament), Men's Soccer (American regular season), along with last year's individual conference champions in Swimming & Diving. Three club national championship teams from Hockey, Women's Flag Football and Women's Soccer will also be recognized. The football team hits the home stretch of its 2025 schedule, with three home games remaining in the final four weeks of the regular season. Following tomorrow's game versus Tulsa, FAU travels to Tulane next Saturday before hosting Connecticut and East Carolina in the final two weeks.

headline: Pads Off with Jayden Sweeney
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì This week's Inside the Owls Burrow's Pads Off features redshirt junior S Jayden Sweeney. The show airs each week on FansDuel Sports Network Florida. Sweeney joined the Owls in the summer of 2025 and quickly solidified himself as an every game player. With three starts and action in each of the team's eight games, the Birmingham, Alabama native has 22 tackles, including 12 solo. Sweeney has 1.5 tackles for a loss and has added a pass breakup and a quarterback hurry. PADS OFF CELEBRATING 25 YEARS Click HERE for 25 Years Celebration Content. COMPLETE 2025 SCHEDULE Click HERE.
